author: Special Correspondent
text:
As cities such as Chennai and Visakhapatnam expand, policymakers must address the growing demands of rapid urbanisation, said United States Department of Commerce Deputy Secretary Bruce Andrews. Speaking at a conference on Smart Cities organised by the Indo-American Chamber of Commerce and the US Department of Commerce here on Thursday, Mr. Andrews said that Smart Cities represented the future of urbanisation, technology and sustainability, not just in India, but around the world.

He led a trade delegation of officials and 18 tech companies from the United States. “Building the Smart Cities of the future requires all of us to work together and share lessons from around the world, just as we did in Paris during the climate summit,” said Mr. Andrews.

“Three hundred million people are expected to move to India’s cities over the next twenty years, roughly the entire population of the United States. This means that the decisions that India makes today about how to handle that growth will have huge implications for the future of this country, and the world. India has the chance to be a leader in the world’s efforts to address global challenges such as climate change as well as a leader in the competition for capital and top talent,” said Mr. Andrews.
